title: Lavender Tallow Balm: The Weird Jar That Fixed My Winter Face
body:
Okay so my skin just gave up. Like, full surrender. It was January, the kind of cold that makes the air feel like static, and my face decided to become a topographical map of dry, flaky misery. Around my nose. My forehead. Even my eyelids felt like parchment. I was using that fancy La Mer cream my sister gave me for Christmas—the one that costs more than my weekly groceries—and it was doing exactly nothing. Just sitting there, all expensive and useless. My skin was still tight, still cracking when I smiled. I was desperate. And then I saw this thing online, a whipped tallow balm. Beef fat. For your face. I stared at the screen. Really? That’s where we’re at?

But the description said lavender, for sleep. My brain was a buzzing hive at night anyway, so why not. I figured it couldn’t make things worse. I ordered the jar from this little Etsy shop, some person in France making it by hand. It arrived in a plain box, no fancy packaging. Just a simple glass jar. I opened it.

## How Beef Tallow Ended Up on My Nightstand

So the whole beef tallow for skin thing. It sounds medieval, right? You picture a cauldron. But then I read a bit—when I was waiting for it to ship, because I have no patience—and it sort of makes a weird kind of sense. Tallow from grass-fed cows is supposed to be really similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum, or whatever. So instead of just sitting on top of your skin like a plastic wrap (looking at you, La Mer), it actually sinks in. It’s like giving your skin back what the winter stole. The one I got is whipped, so it’s not like scooping grease from a pan. It’s fluffy. Different.

I was still skeptical. I mean, come on. Beef fat. I showed the jar to my partner and he just blinked and said, “You’re putting cow on your face now?” Helpful. Very supportive.

But back to the skin disaster. Before this, I’d tried everything. The La Mer. That Drunk Elephant Protini Polypeptide Cream that everyone raves about. Felt nice for an hour, then back to desert mode. Even slathered myself in Aquaphor, which just made me a sticky, shiny mess that stuck to my pillowcase. Nothing worked for more than a few minutes. My hands were bad too, from all the washing and sanitizer. Knuckles red and split. A whole situation.

## What This Lavender Tallow Stuff Actually Does

The first night I used it, I was just…tired. It was like 11 PM. I’d been doomscrolling. The lamp was making that faint buzzing sound it does. I scooped a tiny bit out with my finger. It was solid but soft, like cold butter. Rubbed it between my palms to warm it up. The smell hit me then.

It’s not a perfume lavender. Not like a candle or a cleaning product. It’s…herbal. Green almost. Like crushed lavender plants, stems and all. A little earthy underneath. It doesn’t smell like dessert, which I was worried about. It smells like an old garden. Timeless, I guess you could say, but in a real way, not a marketing way. I put it on my face. Neck too. My parched hands got the leftovers.

Here’s the weird part. It didn’t feel greasy. Not like I expected. It felt…rich. It melted in. My skin drank it. There was no shiny film. Just softness. I went to bed thinking, well, at least I’ll smell nice.

I woke up and my face didn’t feel tight. That was new. Usually, I’d wake up and it would feel like a mask had dried and hardened overnight. This time, nothing. Just skin. Normal skin. I touched my cheek. Still soft. No new flakes around my nose. I was confused. Was this a fluke?

I kept using it. Just at night. After a week, the cracks on my knuckles started to close up. The rough, scaly patches on my elbows—gone. I didn’t even put it there on purpose, just the residue from my face routine. My face stopped feeling like it was going to split open every time I went outside. The wind would hit it and instead of wincing, I’d just…be fine. It was bizarre. In a good way.

Wait, where was I going with this. Oh, the texture. It’s hard to describe. It’s not a cream. It’s a balm. Whipped, so it’s airy. When you scoop it, it holds its shape. Then it melts from your body heat. It doesn’t feel heavy. It just feels…right. I don’t know how else to say it.

## My Skin Now & That Random Thing I Remembered

So it’s been a few months. I’m on my second jar. I use it every night without fail. It’s part of the ritual now: wash face, tallow balm, try to sleep. The lavender thing—I think it does help? Or maybe I just believe it helps. Either way, I’m out faster. My skin is just…calm. It’s not “glowing” or whatever they say in ads. It’s not perfect. I still get a spot sometimes. But it’s *healthy*. It doesn’t hurt. It doesn’t flake. It just exists peacefully on my face, which is all I ever wanted.

This reminds me of my grandma. Totally random. She used to use lard on her hands in the winter. She’d keep a little tin by the sink. I thought it was so gross as a kid. Now I’m like…oh. You were onto something. She didn’t have fancy French whipped tallow balm, but the principle was there. Work with what your body understands. Not against it.

I told my mom about it. She has psoriasis, bad on her elbows. I gave her my first jar when it was half empty. She texted me last week: “What was that cow stuff? My elbows aren’t sandpaper anymore.” High praise.

I got the jar from **Eesti Etsy poest**, just a person making small batches. No big company. I like that. Feels less like a transaction and more like someone sharing a thing that works.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. Obviously. I already did.

It’s not magic. It’s not going to make you look 20 again. But if your skin is angry, dry, stressed-out from winter or just life, it’s like hitting the reset button. It gives your skin what it needs to fix itself. It’s simple. One ingredient, plus the lavender oil. That’s it. No 30-step serum routine. Just a little scoop of this weird, wonderful stuff.

For dry skin, for winter damage, for just needing your skin barrier to not be a crumbling wall…this tallow balm works. I’m a convert. A slightly surprised, very relieved convert.

Anyway. If you’re curious about natural skincare and everything else has let you down, maybe give beef tallow a shot. It sounds strange. It is strange. But sometimes strange works.

---

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, it sounds wild, but it actually is. Because it’s so close to our own skin’s sebum, it absorbs deep instead of clogging things up. It’s like superfood for your skin barrier, especially when it’s freaking out from cold or dryness.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience. And I can get clogged pores easy. This stuff melts right in. It’s non-comedogenic, which is a fancy way of saying it shouldn’t block pores. It just sinks in and does its job.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
It’s a real herbal lavender smell. Not sweet or fake. More like you’re brushing past a lavender bush in a garden. Earthy, green, calming. It’s not strong, just a gentle scent that fades pretty fast. Mostly you just feel really, really hydrated.

So yeah. That’s my tallow story. My skin’s happy, I’m sleeping a bit better, and I don’t dread looking in the mirror every winter morning anymore. Can’t ask for much more than that.
